Narrative:
The content of this report is unchanged from the initial report submitted on November 25, 2024 [REDACTED, MAY CONTAIN CONFIDENTIAL BUSINESS INFORMATION]. 
On November [XXX], 2024 Waymo received notice of an allegation that a Waymo Autonomous Vehicle (Waymo AV) operating in Los Angeles, California may have been in a low-speed collision with a non-motorist (pedestrian) on [XXX] near [XXX]. 
On November [XXX], 2024 at 4:04 AM PT a Waymo AV operating in Los Angeles, California was traveling northwest on [XXX] when it began to slow to yield to a pedestrian crossing the street ahead from right to left. After the pedestrian had crossed the path of the Waymo AV, the Waymo AV began to accelerate slightly then immediately began to slow again as the pedestrian turned around and approached the Waymo AV. As the Waymo AV was slowing, the pedestrian may have made contact with the driver side of the Waymo AV. 
At the time of the possible impact, the Waymo AVs Level 4 ADS was engaged in autonomous mode. The pedestrian later claimed to have a minor injury.  The Waymo AV did not sustain any damage. 
Even though this event may involve intentional contact by the pedestrian and the occurrence of actual contact between the Waymo AV and the pedestrian is not clear, Waymo is reporting this event as a crash under Request No. 1 of Standing General Order 2021-01 because a vulnerable road user (pedestrian) influenced the driving task of a vehicle involved and reportedly sustained a minor injury as a result of the event. Waymo may supplement or correct its reporting with additional information as it may become available.

On Wednesday, May [XXX], 2024 at approximately 3:45pm PST, a Nuro Prius operating in manual mode bumped a pedestrian at the intersection of [XXX] and [XXX] in Palo Alto, California.
The Nuro Prius was in autonomous mode when it approached the intersection and came to a stop at the stop bar on [XXX]. It is a two-way stop with the traffic on [XXX] having right of way. The Nuro Prius nudged forward due to an occlusion.
The Nuro operator judged the nudging to be too far and disengaged autonomous mode to reverse in manual. When reversing, the operator bumped a pedestrian crossing the street behind the Nuro Prius. The pedestrian was not injured and after speaking with the operator, left the scene. There was no damage to the vehicle and law enforcement was not involved.

On December 15, 2023, GM Cruise Holdings LLC ("Cruise") filed an update Incident Report (the "Report") under the Second Amended Standing General Order 2021-01, dated April 5, 2023 (the "Order") General Motors LLC (GM) manufactured the Cruise-operated motor vehicle involved in the incident summarized in the Incident Report. Because GM is also a Reporting Entity under the Order, GM is submitting a duplicate of the redacted public copy of the Report. GM has selected "Unknown" in the "ADS version" and "ODD time" fields solely to avoid a second submission of nonpublic Cruise CBI GM is in possession of Cruise's responses to these fields, and incorporates Cruise's responses into this submission by reference. GM's submission is based on facts supplied to GM by Cruise. GM has not investigated the alleged incident and currently believes, based on a reasonable inquiry, that it has no independent knowledge of the facts in the Report. (Reference file: 30412-6395-4).

Cruise is submitting this updated report to indicate in the Post-Crash Information section that it has received a California Highway Patrol Traffic Collision Report in connection with the reported incident.  There are no other changes to Cruise's previous submission (30412-6395-3): A Cruise autonomous vehicle (AV), operating in driverless autonomous mode, was at a complete stop in response to a red light on southbound [XXX] at the intersection with [XXX]. A dark colored Nissan Sentra was also stopped in the adjacent lane to the left of the AV. As the Nissan Sentra and the AV proceeded through the intersection after the light turned green, a pedestrian entered the crosswalk on the opposite side of [XXX] across from the vehicles and proceeded through the intersection against a red light. The pedestrian passed completely through the AVs lane of travel but stopped mid-crosswalk in front of the Nissan Sentra. Shortly thereafter, the Nissan Sentra made contact with the pedestrian, deflecting the pedestrian in front of the AV. The AV braked aggressively but, shortly thereafter, made contact with the pedestrian. The AV then attempted to pull over out of traffic, pulling the individual forward, rather than remaining stationary. The driver of the Nissan Sentra left the scene shortly after the collision. Police and Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were called to the scene and the pedestrian was transported by EMS. On November 2, 2023, Cruise submitted a voluntary recall report to NHTSA relating to the AVs response after the collision, based on updated analysis that Cruise performed since the filing of the previous submissions.

There are no updates related to this incident since the original submission on August 27, 2023.  A Cruise autonomous vehicle ("AV"), operating in driverless autonomous mode, was at a complete stop in response to a red light on southbound [XXX] at the intersection with [XXX]. A pedestrian was standing on the corner adjacent to the AV while the AV was stopped. The AV began proceeding forward after the light turned green. After the AV began proceeding forward, the pedestrian stepped off the curb into the crosswalk in front of the AV. The AV swerved and then braked, but the pedestrian made contact with the AV while the AV was traveling approximately 1.4 mph. This caused no damage to the AV. Police and Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were called to the scene. The pedestrian was transported by EMS. [REDACTED, MAY CONTAIN CONFIDENTIAL BUSINESS INFORMATION]

A Zoox vehicle in autonomy was proceeding at approximately 2mph towards an exit of a private hotel driveway in Las Vegas, Nevada when it was struck on its right front fender by two individuals involved in an altercation who had darted out from the side of the roadway. The right front fender of the Zoox vehicle was dented. The two individuals fled the scene and Zoox is not aware of any reported injuries. We question whether this interaction meets the reporting requirements nevertheless, we are submitting this report out of an abundance of caution. This 10-Day update provides complete information for this incident.

A Cruise autonomous vehicle ("Cruise AV") operating in supervised autonomous mode was driving Westbound on [XXX] between [XXX] and [XXX] when a pedestrian ran in front of the AV. The Cruise AV stopped for the pedestrian and, moments later, the pedestrian began yelling and approaching the Cruise AV. The Cruise AV operator disengaged the Cruise AV from autonomous mode to leave the scene. The Cruise AV operator drove the vehicle forward and maneuvered away from the pedestrian, but the pedestrian continued to approach the Cruise AV and jumped onto the hood of the Cruise AV. The pedestrian fell in front of the Cruise AV and remained there until later fleeing the scene. The injury status of the pedestrian is unknown and a police report was later filed. [REDACTED CONFIDENTIAL BUSINESS INFORMATION]
